You are given a number $n$ representing the number of vertices in a tree. You are also given a number $k$ representing the number of vertices for which you know the distances to all other vertices. 

The input consists of $k$ lines, each containing $n$ integers. The $j$-th integer on the $i$-th line represents the distance from the $i$-th vertex to the $j$-th vertex.

Your task is to construct any tree that satisfies the given distance information or determine if such a tree cannot exist. If a tree exists, output $n-1$ lines, each containing two vertices connected by an edge in the tree.

You are given a number of points and distances between some pairs of points.  Reconstruct a possible tree (a connected graph with no cycles) that could have produced these distances, or say that no such tree exists.
